Award.AwardTitle: CI-ADDO-NEW: ASTERIX: A Community Software Platform for Big Data Research, Analysis, and Management

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Vast quantities of digital information are being generated today on a daily basis through social networks, blogs, online communities, news sources, and mobile applications as well as our increasingly sensed surroundings. Tremendous insight can be gained by storing and making such ?Big Data? available for exploration in a wide variety of domains. Likely beneficiaries include business, social sciences, public health, national security, political science, public safety, medicine, and government policy. Researchers exploring these benefits need software to manage and analyze Big Data, and researchers investigating algorithms and programming models for Big Data can benefit tremendously by being provided with shared building blocks to use as a foundation for their efforts.

Over the past 3.5 years we have developed an initial version of AsterixDB, a powerful new Big Data Management System (BDMS) for scalably storing, managing, searching, and analyzing collections of Big Data using clusters of commodity computers. AsterixDB has a layered code base that consists of a scalable runtime platform (Hyracks), a model-neutral framework for parallel query compilation for Big Data (Algebricks), and the end-user-targeted AsterixDB BDMS itself. This NSF project is turning AsterixDB and its internal software stack into robust, supported, open-source resources for use by the Big Data applications and technology research communities. AsterixDB and its components will be helpful in training students in Computer Science and other data-related sciences, at universities everywhere, about Big Data technologies. This is critical for addressing the information explosion being brought to us courtesy of social media and the mobile Web.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Vast quantities of digital information are being generated on a daily basis through social networks, blogs, online communities, news sources, and mobile applications as well as from sources in our increasingly sensed world. Tremendous value and insight can be gained by warehousing the emerging “Big Data” and making it available for querying and analysis. Domains that stand to greatly benefit from progress in Big Data management include business, social science, public health, national security, political science, public safety, medicine, and government policy. Appropriate software systems are critical to managing and analyzing Big Data, and researchers studying new algorithms and programming models for Big Data can benefit tremendously from the availability of shared platforms and building blocks to provide a foundation for their efforts.

With initial NSF funding, the ASTERIX project team at UC Irvine and UC Riverside developed an initial version of AsterixDB, a Big Data Management System (BDMS), to support scalable storage, management, searching, and analysis of mass quantities of semi-structured data. The result was a layered code base with a scalable dataflow runtime engine (Hyracks), a framework for building parallel query compilers (Algebricks), and of course the overall system itself (AsterixDB). The results of this effort were provided without restrictions to the community via a UC-based open-source release in mid2013, with over 250K lines of code, when the first NSF project was ending. Functionally, at the time of its release, AsterixDB became the first open-source, shared-nothing, parallel data management platform available to the community at large.

The focus of this Community Research Infrastructure (CRI) project has been to harden and further evolve AsterixDB and its underlying software layers for use as software infrastructure to benefit both the Big Data applications and platform technology research communities. Accomplishments to this end during the course of this project have included the following:

1. AsterixDB evolved from being an open-source university prototype to become Apache AsterixDB, a top-level project of the Apache Software Foundation (http://asterixdb.apache.org/).

2. AsterixDB has been chosen as the core technology for a new Big Data analytics product offering that is being worked on by one of the leading software vendors in the NoSQL platform space.

3. The underlying software layers of AsterixDB have been picked up and used as a foundation by other projects related to Big Data management, e.g., by the Apache VXQuery project and by researchers at other UC System campuses working on various new storage and query processing ideas.

4. The AsterixDB system has been used at a number of universities worldwide for research and teaching related to Big Data and NoSQL technologies; more than 700 students have used the system in classes.

5. AsterixDB is currently being used by domain researchers at a number of UC campuses and elsewhere in the world for managing and analyzing social media data in disciplines including public health, social science, and political science.

This NSF CRI funding together with a set of industrial donations that the CRI grant helped to inspire, allowed to significantly advance the quality and performance of the AsterixDB system.
